'speaker_7': 'In 2013, City Council adopted the Language Access Policy and amended it in 2015 to address the use of children as interpreters except for in cases of emergency. 'speaker_7': 'The policy establishes standards and procedures for providing language access to city services, programs and resources in the top three languages spoken in Long Beach, which are Spanish, Combi and Tagalog. This includes coordination of a bilingual staff directory and training for bilingual staff so that they can provide interpretation and translation services as needed.'

'speaker_7': 'The policy also includes over the phone interpretation recorded outgoing messages for city phone lines, interpretation at public and community meetings, and translation of city documents. 'speaker_7': '. In order to implement the policy consistently across all departments. A language access policy kit or lap kit was created to train city staff and promote language services. The lap kit consists of a brochure for staff which you should all have a copy of that details all of the services available.'

'speaker_7': 'A quick fax card is a handy reference guide and a stand up counter display also referred to as the I Speak Cards, which lists the top ten languages in L.A. County. The 30 minute lap training provides city staff with an overview of the policy, the services and how to access them.'

'speaker_7': 'In fiscal year 2017, we conducted 18 staff trainings directly reaching 441 employees. As of right now, we have seven more trainings scheduled for the next couple of months and we invite any city staff to request lap kit trainings from us to ensure that all residents who speak a language other than English can easily access city services.'

'speaker_7': 'We also maintain a bilingual staff directory of 647 city staff who receive bilingual skill pay when they provide translation or interpretation. 'speaker_7': 'The bilingual staff directory is updated every six months and is available on the city's intranet.
